column3: Thanks, I chedked that the key fingerprint `590B7292695AFFA5B672CBB2E13FC145CD3F4304` matches what is used to sign gitian releases.\n\nSame as for #20846: I've been unable to get this key from keyservers, do you have it published somehwere?

It should be at `hkps://keys.openpgp.org` and `hkps://keyserver.ubuntu.com:443` (checking the other ones in my gpg.conf now).
I can probably dump it in --armor in the commit message ?

EDIT: It's also at `hkps://pgp.ocf.berkeley.edu`
EDIT 2: Added it in the commit message too.
> It should be at hkps://keys.openpgp.org\n\nYou'll need to verify your email with them to make it downloadable, I think

> EDIT 2: Added it in the commit message too.\n\nI think putting it in the commit message is a good idea, though, I wouldn't clearsign the exported public key with the key itself. It seems a bit like putting scissors in a package that needs scissors to open ðŸ™‚
Is this is a case of the more the better with Gitian keys? Or are we happy with the number of these post merging this?

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #20846 (Add benthecarman to keys.txt by benthecarman)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to

> Is this is a case of the more the better with Gitian keys? Or are we happy with the number of these post merging this?\n\nThis is a case of people who have been regularly performing gitian builds adding their keys to this file. See https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gitian.sigs/issues/1427.
